The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Comments_List: I learned about social contract theory and historiography.
How political philosophy developed over time.
Critical thinking. Writing skills. Textual analysis.
I definitely gained a personal appreciation for comparative politics, especially comparative political economy.
The strength of the course is the syllabus.

I liked the curriculum overall as it seemed to cover many of the major works in political theory. I feel more confident in my understanding of the ideas that have formed the foundations of political philosophy. I would have liked to read more works by women/ethnic minorities as it seems more relevant to society today. The lectures were lower in quality compared to the other lectures in Directed Studies, however, and I think it could be improved.
I Didnt understand how Nietzsche fit in with HP. I also wished there was more history mixed in with the abundance of political thought this semester.
It's a great course with a fantastic reading list, I wish the professor and specific class I took had been more able to engage me and my peers with the material.
Yes, if they are interested in political thought that form the foundations of political society today.
Yes. DS HP is a life changing experience.
DS H&P second semester is a terrific course, and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in political philosophy.
